DIALOGUE BEFORE: NPCMLiamBinet: Maybe you could help me with something.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm not allowed to leave the Institute, but I'm really curious about the Commonwealth.
Maybe you could tell me about it. What's it like, you know, up on the surface?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: It's great to see people rebuilding civilization. There's a real sense of hope.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: It's great to see people rebuilding civilization. There's a real sense of hope.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm glad to hear that.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: I know what you're thinking. Why should I care? I'm safe down here, right?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: It's a wasteland. People are barely surviving up there.
RESPONSE TEXT: Yeah, I had a feeling it was pretty bad.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: I know what you're thinking. Why should I care? I'm safe down here, right?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Well, let me put it this way. You're much better off down here.
RESPONSE TEXT: I know, and I feel pretty lucky that I am.
People up there have it so much worse.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: I know what you're thinking. Why should I care? I'm safe down here, right?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What makes you so curious about the surface?
RESPONSE TEXT: Because it's the only place I'm not allowed to go.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: I know what you're thinking. Why should I care? I'm safe down here, right?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm glad to hear that.
RESPONSE TEXT: I know what you're thinking. Why should I care? I'm safe down here, right?
I guess it's because of something my dad once told me.
He said, contrary to others might say, science should never be dispassionate.
In fact, compassion should be one of our most important values.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: If more scientists had thought that way, the bomb might never have been invented.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If more scientists had thought that way, the bomb might never have been invented.
RESPONSE TEXT: Wow, I never thought of it that way, but you're right.
I can't imagine what it must have been like to be there when the bombs fell.
I think I'd have nightmares for the rest of my life.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: Well, it was nice to meet you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Real science should deal in facts, not feelings.
RESPONSE TEXT: Most people down here would agree with you. My dad's kind of independent in that way.
He's got some different ideas and he's not afraid to say so. I admire him for it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: Well, it was nice to meet you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I can see both sides, really.
RESPONSE TEXT: I can understand that.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: Well, it was nice to meet you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What do you think?
RESPONSE TEXT: I think he's right. If we're going to make a better future, it should be a future where people care about each other.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: Well, it was nice to meet you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I think I'd have nightmares for the rest of my life.
RESPONSE TEXT: Well, it was nice to meet you.
It's alright, I'm used to being ignored.
Maybe you could help me with something.
DIALOGUE AFTER: LiamBinet: I'm not allowed to leave the Institute, but I'm really curious about the Commonwealth.

RESPONSE TEXT: Why can't a synth be a person too? I don't really see the difference.
Dad says I'm as good as he is with computers.
I'm trying to learn chess, but the computer always beats me.
SCRIPT NOTES: Sheepish admission, but with a smile

RESPONSE TEXT: The Coursers give me the creeps, you know? They seem, I don't know, cold.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Liam: I want to frame Justin Ayo.
RESPONSE TEXT: Ever since Doctor Zimmer left, he's been out of control.
He and his Coursers have been pushing people around and threatening them to get what he wants.
When he came after my dad, that was the last straw.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: If he's as bad as you say, then he needs to go.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Think of all the synths I could help then!
RESPONSE TEXT: I guess there's only one thing left to do. I'll tell my dad about how I think Justin Ayo's been secretly freeing the synths.
I've got a motive for him, too. The way I see it, it's a play to make sure everyone depends on the SRB.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I said I'd give you my spare glasses, and here they are. Thanks again for your help!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm investigating synth escapes.
RESPONSE TEXT: I already told Justin Ayo that my dad has nothing to do with that.
I guess he didn't believe me so he sent you instead. That guy's a real jerk.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Listen, I know what Justin Ayo believes, but he's wrong. My dad's not helping synths get away.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm here to prove that your father is helping synths escape.
RESPONSE TEXT: No he's not! First that Ayo guy tries to accuse him and now you.
Everyone's trying to blame my dad, but he didn't do it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Listen, I know what Justin Ayo believes, but he's wrong. My dad's not helping synths get away.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Oh, just looking around.
RESPONSE TEXT: Aw, come on, you're not going to fool me that easily.
You're here for a reason, I can tell. So what is it?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I'm investigating synth escapes.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Know anything about a remote computer access?
RESPONSE TEXT: Um... no, I don't know anything about that.
Why would you ask... oh, I know what this is about.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Listen, I know what Justin Ayo believes, but he's wrong. My dad's not helping synths get away.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I guess he didn't believe me so he sent you instead. That guy's a real jerk.
RESPONSE TEXT: Listen, I know what Justin Ayo believes, but he's wrong. My dad's not helping synths get away.
I guess he could get into real trouble if they decide he's guilty anyway.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: If your father is innocent, then there's nothing to worry about.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Maybe. Your father is important, but so are the synths.
RESPONSE TEXT: Yeah, that's what everyone keeps saying. It's like the synths are more important than people.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I wish everyone would just leave my dad alone.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Do you know anything that might help me prove his innocence?
RESPONSE TEXT: I don't know anything that would help. I wish I did.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I wish everyone would just leave my dad alone.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Yeah, that's what everyone keeps saying. It's like the synths are more important than people.
RESPONSE TEXT: I wish everyone would just leave my dad alone.
I mean, why is it such a big deal if a few synths escape? We have more than enough here.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Liam, I can only help if you're honest with me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Liam, I can only help if you're honest with me.
RESPONSE TEXT: I already told you., I don't know anything about it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I guess I'll get out of your way, then.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That's not the point. It's a matter of trust and loyalty.
RESPONSE TEXT: My father's been loyal to the Institute every day of his life. Anyone who questions that is a fool.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I guess I'll get out of your way, then.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Is there anyone else who might want to help the synth?
RESPONSE TEXT: I don't know. You figure it out. Just leave my dad out of it, okay?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I guess I'll get out of your way, then.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I already told you., I don't know anything about it.
RESPONSE TEXT: I guess I'll get out of your way, then.
I wouldn't want to interfere with your stupid investigation.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: PlayerVoiceFemale01: You're the one helping synths escape. Why?
RESPONSE TEXT: So, you figured it out. Nice work. Nobody else down here could. I'm not surprised it took someone from outside.
At first I just wanted to see if I could get away with it. It was a challenge, you know?
But then I realized the synths are really just like us, except without any freedom.
I decided to help the ones that wanted to escape, so they can have a better life.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Down here, they're no better than servants. At least on the surface, they'll be free.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Down here, they're no better than servants. At least on the surface, they'll be free.
RESPONSE TEXT: That's all I've ever wanted for them.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Look, now that you know, you have a choice to make. You could tell Justin, but I have a proposal for you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: A better life? It's a living hell up there.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm not forcing them to leave, I'm just, you know, giving them an opportunity.
If they take it, they have to face the same risks as everyone else on the surface, but at least they'll be free.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Look, now that you know, you have a choice to make. You could tell Justin, but I have a proposal for you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You should know that Eve is dead. She died trying to protect you.
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh no... no. I'm so sorry. I had no idea she's grown that attached, or cared that much.
I swear, I didn't mean for that to happen. She was a good person, I promise. She really seemed to love us.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Look, now that you know, you have a choice to make. You could tell Justin, but I have a proposal for you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You should know that Eve is dead. She died trying to protect you.
RESPONSE TEXT: What?! I didn't think she cared that much about us, not enough to hurt someone.
I'm sorry. I'm really sorry. I've made a terrible mistake. I didn't mean for that to happen, I swear.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Look, now that you know, you have a choice to make. You could tell Justin, but I have a proposal for you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What happens to the synths you free?
RESPONSE TEXT: I like to think they go on to live better lives. I hope so, anyway.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: Look, now that you know, you have a choice to make. You could tell Justin, but I have a proposal for you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That's all I've ever wanted for them.
RESPONSE TEXT: Look, now that you know, you have a choice to make. You could tell Justin, but I have a proposal for you.
I want to frame Justin Ayo.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If he's as bad as you say, then he needs to go.
RESPONSE TEXT: I know just what to do.
Go to Justin's quarters and disable the security safeguards on his private terminal.
I'll remotely plant evidence on it that'll make it look like he's the one helping the synths.
Then it's bye-bye Justin Ayo.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Nice try kid, but that's not happening.
RESPONSE TEXT: Well, I guess that's it for me, then. At least now I can prove my dad is innocent.
And don't worry, I won't try to run. I wouldn't know where to go anyway.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Maybe if you offered me the right incentive...
RESPONSE TEXT: Well, I guess I could part with my spare glasses. My dad always says they make me look smarter.
Help me frame Justin, and they're yours.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: If he's as bad as you say, then he needs to go.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Maybe if you offered me the right incentive...
RESPONSE TEXT: I don't have anything to give you, honest. I wish I did.
But think of all the synths you'll be helping! You'd do it for them, right?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: If he's as bad as you say, then he needs to go.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Would that really solve anything? Who would take Justin's place if he were gone.
RESPONSE TEXT: Alana Secord. She's honest, fair and good at what she does.
She'll make a great acting director for the SRB.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: If he's as bad as you say, then he needs to go.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: PlayerVoiceFemale01: I disabled the safeguards.
RESPONSE TEXT: Way ahead of you. I've already accessed the terminal and planted the evidence. Pretty good, huh?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: You're a natural, kid.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're a natural, kid.
RESPONSE TEXT: Yep. Maybe one day I'll even be head of the Robotics division.
SCRIPT NOTES: NO RE-RECORD NEEDED - Just fixed a capitalization error / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Think of all the synths I could help then!
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I guess there's only one thing left to do. I'll tell my dad about how I think Justin Ayo's been secretly freeing the synths.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: It's nothing special.
RESPONSE TEXT: Well, maybe every kid was a computer genius back in your time, but it's pretty rare now.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I guess there's only one thing left to do. I'll tell my dad about how I think Justin Ayo's been secretly freeing the synths.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Liam: I've got a motive for him, too. The way I see it, it's a play to make sure everyone depends on the SRB.
RESPONSE TEXT: I said I'd give you my spare glasses, and here they are. Thanks again for your help!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Liam: I've got a motive for him, too. The way I see it, it's a play to make sure everyone depends on the SRB.
RESPONSE TEXT: Thanks again for your help. a lot of people will be happier with Justin Ayo out of the way, especially my dad.
I didn't think I'd get my dad into so much trouble. I should have thought of that.
Everyone thinks of the synths as machines, but they sure seem like people to me.
I bet the free synths are happier than the ones down here.
Ayo should never have gone after my father.
I wish I could be there to see the look on Justin Ayo's face when he's the one who gets blamed for the escaped synths.
Don't know if we'll see each other again.
Can't believe you sided with Justin.
Guess the idea of synths being free isn't for everyone.
So Justin wins, all thanks to you. Unbelievable.
I... I do know something. I did it. I'm the one who's helping the synths.
SCRIPT NOTES: A reluctant confession. Draw this out a bit. / Apologetic

RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, it's you again. What are you doing here?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I'm investigating synth escapes.

RESPONSE TEXT: Hey, you're that new guy, the one from the vault. What are you doing here?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I'm investigating synth escapes.

RESPONSE TEXT: Probably best to talk about something else right now.

RESPONSE TEXT: But that can't be right. Heck, you look positively normal to me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Patriot: But that can't be right. Heck, you look positively normal to me.
RESPONSE TEXT: Uh, no offense.

RESPONSE TEXT: I'm not sure if we could ever make the surface actually a decent place to live.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Patriot: But that doesn't mean we shouldn't at least try to help, you know?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Patriot: I'm not sure if we could ever make the surface actually a decent place to live.
RESPONSE TEXT: But that doesn't mean we shouldn't at least try to help, you know?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: So much to take in. But, wait.
RESPONSE TEXT: With you in the picture, I have this idea. To rescue a lot of synths at once.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Patriot: But we'll need help. Where's he working now? Right, let's go to the West Atrium.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Patriot: With you in the picture, I have this idea. To rescue a lot of synths at once.
RESPONSE TEXT: But we'll need help. Where's he working now? Right, let's go to the West Atrium.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: The Railroad sent me to look for someone they call Patriot. That's you.
RESPONSE TEXT: What? The Railroad? As in the Railroad?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Patriot: And they gave me a code name, too?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Patriot: What? The Railroad? As in the Railroad?
RESPONSE TEXT: And they gave me a code name, too?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Patriot: I kept sending synths to the surface hoping someone would help them.

RESPONSE TEXT: Z1-14. It's me.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Z1-14: Sir. Do you require something?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Z1-14: Sir. Do you require something?
RESPONSE TEXT: It's OK, Z1. He's a friend. He's with the Railroad.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Z1-14: Meeting here is dangerous. And you bring a stranger.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Z1-14: Sir. Do you require something?
RESPONSE TEXT: It's OK, Z1. She's a friend. She's with the Railroad.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Z1-14: Meeting here is dangerous. And you bring a stranger.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Z1-14: I've never met another human willing to help... But, sir, we must make this quick.
RESPONSE TEXT: Right now, how many synths want to escape, Z1?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Z1-14: The ones I know for certain. Thirteen.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Z1-14: The ones I know for certain. Thirteen.
RESPONSE TEXT: That'll take forever. Let's free those thirteen all in one go.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Z1-14: I would do anything for my people. But how do we get them to the teleporter?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Z1-14: The old maintenance tunnels that lead there are always sealed. By the SRB.
RESPONSE TEXT: If I can find a way to open those doors, could you get your synths to the teleporter room?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Z1-14: Yes. We'll talk later. Someplace more secure.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I... I thought only Mr. Binet cared. But your friends actually fight for us?
RESPONSE TEXT: That's what the Railroad does, Z1. He's from the surface.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Z1-14: I've never met another human willing to help... But, sir, we must make this quick.
SCRIPT NOTES: Whispered, vouching for the PC / Pleading

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I... I thought only Mr. Binet cared. But your friends actually fight for us?

DIALOGUE AFTER: Patriot: You're willing to help, right? I can't do this alone.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Of course I'll help you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I won't help you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Patriot: The original security program was called Code Defender. Revolutionary stuff. We still have terminals running version 1 mothballed in storage.

RESPONSE TEXT: But if you could get me a pre-war admin password from the surface, I could log right in.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I'll find it for you.

SCRIPT NOTES: Excited, then deflates a little / Nervous

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: A friend named Tinker Tom cracked your encryption.
RESPONSE TEXT: He must've had some serious hardware to pull that off. Wow.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Who are you?
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm Liam Binet. My father runs Synth Development.
And everyone knows who you are.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: A friend named Tinker Tom cracked your encryption.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Trinity? What's that?
RESPONSE TEXT: Trinity is an encryption system, with a cipher or key cut up into many pieces.
You need several pieces, in the correct order, to unlock it.
I put a Trinity piece with every synth I helped escape. It was long shot, but I was hoping some good Samaritan would connect it all together.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: A friend named Tinker Tom cracked your encryption.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: He must've had some serious hardware to pull that off. Wow.
RESPONSE TEXT: Your message was only one word: "Friend". What did you mean by that?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: The Railroad sent me to look for someone they call Patriot. That's you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What do you think?
RESPONSE TEXT: At the very least, I'm hoping it means you won't turn me in.
But you really are a friend, aren't you?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: The Railroad sent me to look for someone they call Patriot. That's you.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Patriot: And they gave me a code name, too?
RESPONSE TEXT: I kept sending synths to the surface hoping someone would help them.
I hoped the Railroad got to some of them, but I never knew for certain.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: You've saved a lot of synths.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You've saved a lot of synths.
RESPONSE TEXT: So much to take in. But, wait.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Patriot: With you in the picture, I have this idea. To rescue a lot of synths at once.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If you met them, trust me, you wouldn't be that impressed.
RESPONSE TEXT: They've eluded the SRB for decades. They've got to be incredible.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Patriot: With you in the picture, I have this idea. To rescue a lot of synths at once.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Why are you helping synths?
RESPONSE TEXT: At first I just wanted to see if I could get away with it. It was a challenge, you know?
But then I realized the synths are really just like us, except without any freedom.
I decided to help the ones that wanted to escape, so they can have a better life.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: You've saved a lot of synths.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: How did you help synths escape?
RESPONSE TEXT: Through hacking. The departments focus their best talent on the hard science. Why waste time on terminal security, right?
SCRIPT NOTES: Having a laugh at the stupid authorities

RESPONSE TEXT: The SRB is the exception. And, unfortunately, they control which synths go to the surface.
SCRIPT NOTES: Not laughing now, they worry him

RESPONSE TEXT: But a forged work order from, let's say, BioScience can get a hand-picked synth on surface detail.
And it turns out the Railroad was waiting for them. Wow.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: You've saved a lot of synths.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: PlayerVoiceFemale01: Liam. I got you your username and password.
RESPONSE TEXT: You Railroad guys really deliver, you know?
